I looked more into the idea of combining output and bits directories. At present, 'bits' is a subdir of 'output', so we do already have a place to store build artifacts that we don't want uploaded

It doesn't seem difficult to have the build move output/*.[tgz|iso|etc] into 'output/bits' during 'make world' or directly from build_root_image, retaining the correct output/*-latest symlinks as we do so. While doing this, we could also move the triton manifest generation code into 'make live' so that we never risk having a manifest with a stale platform image hash.

All that said, I'm still not sure how much we really care about doing that work, given that (unless I'm mistaken?) it's only jenkins builds that ever bother uploading artifacts to manta or updates.joyent.com anyway. If the facility were there, is this something ~os engineers are likely to avail of?


While digging about here, I also came across an undocumented 'configure-buildvers' file which our MG 'platform-debug' job hasn't been using, but which seems like the perfect candidate to allow the build to create the correct 'platform-debug.tgz' file directly from 'build_live'. If we use this, it would simplify some of the Makefile changes under review.

Do we have to keep this? I only had this because of what MG did, and it would be great not to have to continue that.
That's a result of us running this during gerrit hooks and not wanting to checkout all ./projects for each gerrit commit. I think we're going to still want this.
Oh yes, I basically forgot about that. OK.
Do we really want $3? Don't we want anything at $3 and after? This'll fail if someone ever uses a branch name like dev/foobar.

That's true, though this does mirror what MG has done (and eng.git continues to do) - https://github.com/joyent/mountain-gorilla/#package-versioning and
https://github.com/joyent/eng/blob/master/tools/mk/Makefile.defs#L67

Since branch names are used in Manta artifact file and directory names, it's really problematic to have branches with slashes in them. We have similar assumptions in a few other places (sdc-headnode downloader, agents-installer mk-shar come to mind)

Perhaps we could harden this code some more, but it becomes quite a long line as a result. Here's a sample Makefile fragment:


PLATFORM_BRANCH=$(shell git symbolic-ref HEAD | awk -F/ '{if (NF > 3) { print "unsupported branch: too many / chars"; exit 1;}  print $$3}')
ifneq ($(.SHELLSTATUS), 0)
    $(error "Unable to set PLATFORM_BRANCH")
endif

all:

        echo $(PLATFORM_BRANCH)
Maybe we can just fail fast in these cases?

If we were using this value for anything other than symbolic purposes, I'd agree that failing fast would be correct.

The problem is that when building from Gerrit, it's quite likely that we'll encounter branches with slashes, e.g. 'refs/changes/45/12345/1', so we need to be able to deal with them.

More problematic still, is that detached heads behave strangely when asking for a symbolic ref:

===
timf@iorangi-eth0 (master) git ls-remote | grep 49/5749/5
From https://cr.joyent.us/joyent/illumos-kvm-cmd.git
10d01499dc302f501c63949a7c7d8c7e6c148470	refs/changes/49/5749/5
timf@iorangi-eth0 (master) git fetch origin refs/changes/49/5749/5
From https://cr.joyent.us/joyent/illumos-kvm-cmd
 * branch            refs/changes/49/5749/5 -> FETCH_HEAD
timf@iorangi-eth0 (master) git checkout FETCH_HEAD
Note: checking out 'FETCH_HEAD'.

You are in 'detached HEAD' state. You can look around, make experimental
changes and commit them, and you can discard any commits you make in this
state without impacting any branches by performing another checkout.

If you want to create a new branch to retain commits you create, you may
do so (now or later) by using -b with the checkout command again. Example:

  git checkout -b <new-branch-name>

HEAD is now at 10d0149 fix live migration
timf@iorangi-eth0 ((HEAD detached at FETCH_HEAD)) BRANCH=$(git symbolic-ref HEAD | awk '{print $3}')
fatal: ref HEAD is not a symbolic ref
timf@iorangi-eth0 ((HEAD detached at FETCH_HEAD)) echo _"$BRANCH"_
__
timf@iorangi-eth0 ((HEAD detached at FETCH_HEAD))
===

So I think the right answer here is to simply ask for a 'git describe --all' and use $3 as normal for now.

I'm making complementary changes to 'configure' and 'configure_branches_desc' to deal with this state more elegantly (where previous code review feedback asked that we consult the ./projects git repos to determine their branches rather than trust that the 'configure-branches' file was up to date)
Missing period?
Done
nit, the tab alignment seems rather random here, maybe don't bother?
It still seems weird to me that we get a totally different UUID every time we invoke any make targets, but I'm not sure I have a better suggestion.
Yeah, we're only using this in the triton-platform-publish target, so we might as well only set that in the target commands directly.
If you don't wan the cut you can always use 'digest -a sha1 $(PLATFORM_TARBALL)'. Assuming there's only a single file.

Yep, that's better - thanks. MG used openssl in its corresponding target:

https://github.com/joyent/mountain-gorilla/blob/master/Makefile#L2856

maybe allowing publication from a non-illumos machine after a build had completed and had posted its artifacts somewhere, but I agree that since we know we're running on illumos at this point, using digest is better.

I'm wondering how much the output-* directories make sense, now we *also* have a bits dir. Seems like two very similar things? What is the benefit of writing it out somewhere, then having a separate step that just copies them about?

This is so that we can use bits-upload from eng.git. Other Manta/Triton components have a "publish" step which stages changes in ./bits, and a "bits-upload" step which posts to Manta and updates.joyent.com

I'll see whether we can symlink into the bits dir prior to publication and have bits-upload do the right thing. Otherwise changing output-* into bits directories would work, at the risk of breaking any other tools that depend on this layout. 

With the other lullaby changes, we tried to keep them "MG-compatible" to allow us to continue building components with MG even after the lullaby conversions integrated in case of problems. We never actually needed that capability though, so maybe changing this now isn't a big deal.

If we wanted to consolidate, we could probably consolidate the output directories. It'd be nice if the ISO/USB bits had the same symlinking logic and followed what was going on in output. As the person responsible for them, I'm not sure I would do them today.

It doesn't seem unreasonble to have the bits directory have a bunch of other output that the normal build doesn't care about or a different layout. Especially as we'd want to change that layout at eng.git's preferences and not have annoyed developers be a real consideration. Where as if we change the current layout of at least output/ and the platform-latest symlinks, we will have annoyed engineers.

Fair point.

This wad as a whole already definitely requires a build flag-day, so I'm probably well down the path of annoying engineers :-) I'm happy to do the work to re-org the layout of the build artifacts, but won't start that until there's consensus.

For reference, here's what a bits dir looks like on Manta with my current changes, in this case, a full "triton-and-smartos" build:

timf@iorangi-eth0 mls /Joyent_Dev/stor/timf-builds/platform/master-20190411T101956Z/platform
SINGLE_USER_ROOT_PASSWORD.txt
boot-master-20190411T101956Z.tgz
build.log
changelog.txt
configure-branches
images-master-20190411T101956Z.tgz
index.html
md5sums.txt
platform-master-20190411T101956Z.imgmanifest
platform-master-20190411T101956Z.tgz
smartos-20190411T101956Z-USB.img.gz
smartos-20190411T101956Z.iso
smartos-20190411T101956Z.vmwarevm.tar.gz

Our local copy of output/bits/platform needs to be identical, though for convenience, we could add "-latest" symlinks to relevant artifacts.

Having looked into the idea of symlinking from ./bits to the various output-* dirs, that won't work without changes to bits-upload itself as we're intentionally only uploading files and directories (since doing an 'mput' of a symlinked file results in a duplicated object on Manta, which we don't want)

We could easily do things the other way around, retaining output-iso, output-usb, etc. but have their contents symlink into the  output/bits/platform directory.

Ultimately, the inefficiency we're talking about here amounts to a few hundred megabytes being copied around at the end of the build, and built workspaces taking up a bit more space on jenkins agents - maybe not worth the trouble?

I suspect 95+% of non-automated build development is going to happen without ever running the jenkins scripts, so a top-level bits/ directory won't appear. I don't think having it duplicate the bits/ paths from what's in the current output/ directories is the end of the world, particularly if you want to have a consistent view and not deal with the fact that someone could run gmake live out from under you, but not the corresponding targets for the bits directories which would cause the manifests to all be out of date.

I don't feel like symlinking the output/ stuff into the bits directories makes sense, given the likelihood for that to get out of date as described above, unless we are very careful about dependencies (which isn't really the case today). So maybe the above is an answer to John's question?

FWIW, many of us rely on the platform-latest symlink in the output/ directories for development and staying sane (mostly for the non-tgz link so it can be fed straight to ipxe or however we're booting), so it's pretty important that those don't go away. I know that's not happening in your change today. But if we're contemplating other refactoring of how we store output in the normal (gmake live) phase, then we'd need to ensure that it logically still exists. We can deal with it changing if that ultimately leads to a better experience.

I was trying to suggest having the files in bits/ be symlinks, but I'm now less convinced that make sense, due to the fact that manifests would be out of date relative to a gmake live being invoked. So the more I write this, the more I think the duplication is actually a plus and not a minus.

I suppose I'm missing why we can't just directly put stuff where publish puts them now along with convenience symlinks.
That is, we basically have the needed bits of publish inside the normal targets. I realise this means more refactoring how stuff is built.
OK thanks. I don't think we care about MG for this in particular as it's a lot more complicated than other components.

If we're going to refactor everything and make sure manifest generation is up to date with things like gmake live, then that's more likely to be fine. The problem I was trying to point out was that many things like the upload targets don't depend on anything at all, so it seems very likely that we'll have dependencies get out of date. I would not be surprised a person manually trying to use these targets (which they will do since they're here now) will end up uploading an artifact whose manifest has a different checksum than the artifact because of having run gmake live at some point and not realizing that they're not synced at all.

Improving the layout for humans makes sense, but hopefully at some point we can change the automated tools to just construct what they want without changing what humans see, because if everyone developing has to change what they're used to doing every time we want to change how something looks in the artifact storage system, people will get annoyed. So, if it makes sense to change it and we think it'll actually be better, let's do it. Let's just not forget the human cost.

If this stuff changes, we definitely need documentation updates to the smartos-live README, etc. and a much firmer heads up, because otherwise folks basically would have been able to get through this with the standard gmake update; ./configure; gmake live.
So Tim, if you think it's worth at least investigating what this might look like, that'd be good. Or if you don't want to bother, I'm fine with that too I suppose.
Yep. Let me get this next set of changes posted here for review first (test builds running now) and I'll look at the output-dir reorg after that.

Also, will it be OK for us to have items in here that we aren't necessarily uploading / releasing? For example, say we have the ability to build images for other environments or targets, will that then throw things off?

To clarify that a bit more: Say I manually build an iso image for vmware to test on, but then I want to upload the main bits, I probably don't want that uploaded. Or say we in the future have some other form of the image, like we pre-create a KVM/bhyve/other virt image, it'd be great to make sure that doesn't end up leaking into the upload.

Right now, bits-upload will upload all files and directories from the bits dir to Manta and will 'updates-imgadm add' all Triton manifest/image pairs found in the upload area.

If we need the ability to not upload certain files, we'll either need a separate place for those, or come up with an exception mechanism to prevent those bits from being uploaded. 

The model we're following here is the one used for other Manta/Triton images - build them, 'publish' to an upload area, then upload. If that doesn't match the needs of certain flavors of platform build, nothing's stopping us from either changing the model, being careful about what artifacts are "published", or us deciding that model really doesn't fit well here.
This makes me feel like combining the output and bits directories is the wrong approach.
Is the bug filed? Can we refer to it directly here please?
Will do. I hadn't filed a bug, but have done so now - TOOLS-2241
Is the assumption that the other tools that will be required, such as the manta tools are being pulled in manually?

Yes that is the assumption.

That will be correct in our production build environment, where our jenkins agents deliver the manta tools with relevant symlinks in /root/bin, which is on $PATH. Other Manta/Triton components use eng.git:tools/validate-buildenv.sh to verify that these tools are present, 

https://github.com/joyent/eng/blob/master/tools/validate-buildenv.sh#L594

but that script is too strict for smartos-live (notably, it requires that the pkgsrc bootstrap tools are in /opt/tools/bin, needed for buildimage, which smartos-live doesn't use)

I think there's 3 options here, and I'm veering towards the third, but would welcome opinions:

1. simply document the requirement, noting that this is unlikely to impact non-Joyent users of smartos-live who are unlikely to want to  publish artifacts to Manta (any who do would have been using MG before now, and it already made this assumption)

2. adapt validate-buildenv so that smartos-live can use it report on missing build machine requirements, but not report on things smartos-live doesn't need.

3. update 'configure' to look for manta tools and imgadm-cli. Since 'configure' is already installing nodejs from pkgsrc, we could have it also 'npm install -g' those if the packages were missing from $PATH.

Line 525/542 does reference "MANTA_TOOLS_PATH" so if we're doing 3. above, we could omit that.
Given the mere presence of mput is not sufficient, I think I'm fine with 1) personally.
OK, that seems reasonable. I guess given the fact that to successfully succeed you need things like keys on the right servers, there's not much point in doing it here.
Cool.

There was a recent discussion about build cadence, switching Triton to a 4-weekly build, but keeping SmartOS on a biweekly schedule.

The impact there was that for every other biweekly build, we'd need to build both Triton and SmartOS, with interim release builds only needing to build SmartOS. That's more context that we're including here though, and I agree the comment as it stands isn't useful.

Are we really sure we want projects/eng/ not deps/eng/ ?

This is a "submodule vs. projects framework" question I think.

The way we have it now in projects means it fits better with the way smartos-live deals with extra repositories.

The risk of not using eng.git as a submodule, is that smartos-live would be immediately broken by any bad commits to eng.git (with submodules we lock to a specific version of eng.git and need a smartos-live commit to upgrade to a newer version)

This is a trade-off to be sure.  I'm slightly more comfortable with eng-as-a-submodule, but it will need a new top-level directory in smartos-live if we go that route.
Fair enough, I guess this is fine for now.

(We're discussing this in ~os as I write this, and have settled on a potential solution to ease the confusion here, which I'll prototype this week and have a demo sent out)

   (like we now do for illumos-extra targets)

Sure. There was some shenanigans about wanting the manta upload attempt to appear in the log itself, but I'll see if I can remove this and just | tee to the log file instead.
I guess -d is tough, and -F makes sense, but why aren't -c and -i subsumed into PLAT_CONFIGURE_ARGS ? Why do we need separate args there?
This felt more user-friendly - this script tells the user what options it supports rather than expecting them to know what arguments 'configure' supports..

It's not a big deal I suppose, but this isn't complete then. I think anyone can read the description of the CONFIGURE_ARGS option in jenkins and go inspect the script? I'd definitely lean towards less code here.
Is there a reason that the stamps are being manually cleared here? I guess we can't use the gmake update target at all? What if one needs to re-run ./configure between incremental builds?

I was following the advice from https://github.com/joyent/smartos-live/#incremental-development which suggested that by removing the stamps, we get incremental builds of those components.

Is re-running configure between incremental builds something we'd support - perhaps to force an illumos clobber, but switching between debug/nondebug bits across an incremental boundary, or switching compilers between incremental builds seems a bit risky?

While the primary use-case of the 'build_jenkins' script was production jenkins builds themselves (and as such, incremental builds would never happen) I thought that adding this incremental option _might_ be useful when trying to debug the production build on a standalone build machine.
Seems like you can trivially just always remove the stamps regardless of this setting? I actually don't see much point in -i at all - it would just produce a warning if not set?

The intent here was to let developers more easily debug production builds on local systems. If we don't think that's useful (relating to your earlier point, where could do with less logic in build_jenkins) then I'm fine with removing this.
Would we ever do production builds with the -i option? It feels like for the debugging case, someone will likely be manually invoking make targets or using bldenv to dig into things.
No, I don't think we'd ever do a production build with -i. I agree with you about how developers are likely to debug, so let's just remove this option altogether.
What I'm saying is we can just rm -f the stamp files here unconditionally, without any need for inspecting an -i option at all.

I don't understand what's going on with the basename here.

This is back to the old 'Jenkins vs. Gerrit, refs/remotes/origin/master vs refs/remotes/cr/master' ambiguity.

Since Jenkins uses the long-form refs/remotes/origin/master branch name, and sets $BRANCH to that when we launch this script, we have to use the basename of $BRANCH to express it in a form that configure-branches can deal with.

configure-branches doesn't have the same ambiguity of branch names that Jenkins does since the projects framework only ever configures a single 'git remote' per project.
I think this might change somewhat with the most recent discussion we had on #os so we can come back to this if needed.
What does this correspond to? Where does this SHA come from?

Originally the point of this was to set "$ENGBLD_CUSTOM" which then gets used in the description of the platform image manifest.

This code actually predated our inclusion of a list of uniquified hyphen-separated branches from configure-branches in the platform stamp, from the smartos-live Makefile:

458 PUB_BRANCH_DESC         = $(shell ./tools/configure_branches_desc $(PLATFORM_BRANCH))
.
.
461 PLATFORM_STAMP                  = $(PLATFORM_BRANCH)$(PUB_BRANCH_DESC)-$(PLATFORM_TIMESTAMP)

which then appears in the platform manifest from the platform-publish target:

506         cat src/platform.imgmanifest.in | sed \
507             -e "s/UUID/$(PLATFORM_IMAGE_UUID)/" \
508             -e "s/ENGBLD_CUSTOM/$(ENGBLD_CUSTOM)/" \
509             -e "s/VERSION_STAMP/$(PLATFORM_STAMP)/" \
510             -e "s/BUILDSTAMP/$(PLATFORM_STAMP)/" \
511             -e "s/SIZE/$$(stat --printf="%s" $(PLATFORM_TARBALL))/" \
512             -e "s#SHA#$$(digest -a sha1 $(PLATFORM_TARBALL))#" \
513             > $(PUB_PLATFORM_MF)

and ends up appearing in the buildstamp tags field:

$ cat -n src/platform.imgmanifest.in
.
.    19    "description": "SmartDataCenter platform imageENGBLD_CUSTOM",
    20    "tags": {
    21      "smartdc_service": "true",
    22      "buildstamp": "BUILDSTAMP"
    23    },

so we could really drop this hash-based annotation of the platform image description. Perhaps it just adds complexity for little benefit.

So this is supposed to be a sha of the branch master being concatenated? I'm not sure whether it's useful or not, but it definitely needs to be better commented here. It basically looks like a magic number and I don't think I would have guessed how it was derived.

The SHA was a hash of a standard 'configure-branches' file, and was intended as one way of detecting a non-standard build.

Given the improvements I'm making to configure_branches_desc, we really don't need this anymore, so I'm removing it.

Did you consider actually asking the git repositories for their branch? Certainly when developing, configure-branches file is *almost always* out of date, as you switch between different branches etc.

That's a fair point. Initially this was a one-liner which grew into this shell script, but yes it would be much better to use what's _actually_ in the git repository, rather than what we think might be there.

The other advantage of your suggestion is that we can also denote 'dirty' repositories that way.

I'll make this change.

FWIW, most repos today aren't trying to keep themselves dirty or not. illumos-joyent will pretty much always be dirty barring major work. I do agree with asking the repo the branch directly. This should just work like the building of /etc/release does and hopefully you can reuse its code.

Ok, good to know that we're not expecting clean repositories - bits-upload.sh has guards against uploading artifacts that were marked as '-dirty' (all Manta/Triton builds pass that test)

I'll make sure not to include repository dirtiness in artifact names for the platform build though, thanks!
